author_bio:
Born in South Australia in 1964, I moved to the north of Western Australia where I grew up in the country, before moving to Perth in 1974. 

I enjoy gardening, and eating freshly picked fruit and vegetables. I make my own pickles, chutneys, jams, and sauces. 

I'm passionate about preserving the old ways of growing, baking, pickling, cooking.

This blog is a place where I like to share my recipes and discoveries.

Henry Lawson was one of Australia’s most famous and beloved writers, distinguished in both poetry and short stories. He is part of the “Bush Ballad” school of poetry, and more generally the realist tradition of writing. 

He was born on June 17, 1867 in Grenfell, New South Wales. His father worked as a gold prospector and former sailor, and his mother was a feminist and social radical. 

While a young boy, Lawson developed an illness that led to a hearing deficiency, which later became near deafness. This descent into deafness was one of the most important catalysts for his turn to writing.
